_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ed. In the more likely, but remote, alternative case scenario, a failure of the manifold on the tube trailer is described. In this scenario, all tubes are open to accommodate process requirements, and the scenario response dictates manually closing each tube isolation valve by our Emergency Response Team. CEREX uses one tube trailer every 2-3 weeks, and utilizes a "drop and swap" protocol to ensure continual supply to the process. Three unloading spots are

in place; one for the on-line trailer, one for the leaving and one for the arriving trailer. Reorders occur when the Tube trailer is near empty (approximately 3,000 pounds). This protocol limits the maximum amount of aHCl on site at any one time to approximately 25,000 pounds.



C. General accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention program:

The details of these programs are embodied in the documents listed in paragraph (A). In summary, CEREX has implemented systems to prevent an accidental aHCl release that include the following:

    Closed circuit monitoring of the tube trailer unloading area with multi-point monitoring in the facility.

    Emergency response systems that are designed to detect a minor leak (before it becomes a major release) and provide the means to mitigate the impact of a release on the surrounding community. These emergency response systems and procedures include:

   An aHCl multi-point Draeger vapor detection and alarm system that surrounds the tube trailer and process piping with sensors calibrated to trigger an alarm in the event of a leak

   Redundant rupture disk and pressure relief valve in the supply pipe system. The relief exhaust system conveys gas to a "drowning system" to neutralize any escaping gases

    Remote activated "fail-close" emergency block valves located at the tube trailer connection point. When activated, this system will also simultaneously close downstream valves that supply aHCl to the process.

   Cerex alarm systems are integral

to a large site wide alarm network (Ascend Performance Materials manufacturing site)

    Emergency response services provided by Ascend Performance Materials who employs a highly trained hazmat emergency response team for rapid on-site response.



D. Five year accident history:

There have been no accidents in the past five years that have resulted in death, injury, or significant property damage on site, nor any known off-site occurrences of death, injury, evacuations, shelter-in-place, property damage, or environmental damage. In the 45+ year existence of the process which utilizes aHCl, there have been no incidents meeting this criteria.



E. Emergency Response program:

Emergency response program details are embodied in the documents listed in paragraph (A). In summary, the CEREX manufacturing site is located within the Ascend Performance Materials (formerly known as Monsanto Company and Solutia Inc.) Pensacola site boundaries. CEREX is an integral part of the Ascend site emergency response system which includes a site wide emergency alarm system, emergency radio communications, and access to Escambia County's Community Automated Telephone Alert system. First response is provide by Ascend's highly trained hazmat/industrial emergency response team that has the equipment and personnel needed to handle Highly Hazardous Material emergencies.



F. Planned changes to improve safety:

Recent changes have significantly lowered on-site storage quantities of aHCl, thus lowering the potential impact of emergency scenarios. Cerex Advanced Fabrics utilizes a progressive Safety Program that consists of regular safety meetings, a comprehensive safety observation program

and a multi-disciplinary team that drives continuous improvement activities for the safe
